tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This is a numerical calculation problem involving finding the damping factor. It requires understanding the relationship between power, frequency, and damping in a single degree of freedom system, and involves multiple steps to solve. It integrates concepts from vibration theory.

answer_validation.reasoning:
The system is a damped SDOF under harmonic excitation. The two given excitation frequencies correspond to the half-power points (\(-3\,	ext{dB}\)) of the frequency response. For a viscously damped SDOF, the half-power bandwidth relation is \(\omega_2 - \omega_1 = 2\zeta\,\omega_n\), where \(\omega_n\) is the undamped natural frequency in rad/s. The given undamped natural frequency is 10 Hz, so \(\omega_n = 2\pi	imes 10 = 62.8319\,	ext{rad/s}\). The half-power frequencies are \(\omega_1 = 60.9469\,	ext{rad/s}\) and \(\omega_2 = 64.7168\,	ext{rad/s}\). Thus, \(\omega_2 - \omega_1 = 3.7699\,	ext{rad/s}\). Using the bandwidth formula: 

\[\zeta =  rac{\omega_2 - \omega_1}{2\omega_n} =  rac{3.7699}{2	imes 62.8319} \approx 0.03 \; (3\%).\]

This matches the official range 2.95 to 3.05%.

step_by_step: Step 1: Convert the given undamped natural frequency from Hz to rad/s: \(f_n = 10\,\text{Hz} \Rightarrow \omega_n = 2\pi f_n = 2\pi\times 10 = 62.8319\,\text{rad/s}.\)
Step 2: Recognize that the two given excitation frequencies (60.9469 rad/s and 64.7168 rad/s) are the half-power frequencies (where power is half of maximum, i.e., -3 dB points).
Step 3: For a lightly damped SDOF system under harmonic excitation, use the half-power bandwidth relation: \(\omega_2 - \omega_1 = 2\zeta\,\omega_n\).
Step 6: Express the damping factor in percent: \(\zeta \times 100 \approx 3\%\).

topic.name: Mechanical vibrations of single-degree-of-freedom systems
topic.syllabus_ref: Vibration and Structural Dynamics -> Single degree of freedom systems (free and forced vibration, damping, resonance)

concepts.name: Damping ratio (damping factor) of SDOF systems
Natural frequency in Hz vs rad/s
Resonance and power in vibrating systems

essential: Concept of natural frequency and its units (Hz vs rad/s)
Definition and physical meaning of damping ratio \(\zeta\)
Frequency response of a damped SDOF under harmonic excitation
Half-power (−3 dB) concept and bandwidth in vibration/controls
helpful: Bode plots and resonance in control systems
Logarithmic scale for power and decibels

Main Concept: requires: SDOF vibration model and equation of motion
requires: Definition of damping ratio and natural frequency
requires: Understanding of forced vibration and resonance peak
enables: Experimental identification of damping from frequency response
enables: Design of structures and components to avoid excessive vibration

difficulty_factors: Requires recalling the specific half-power bandwidth formula
Requires careful conversion from Hz to rad/s
Students may confuse displacement amplitude half-power with power half-power

textbook_references.author: William T. Thomson, Marie Dillon Dahleh
textbook_references.chapter_title: Response of Single Degree of Freedom Systems to Harmonic Excitation

video_references.topic_covered: Resonance, peak response and effect of damping in SDOF systems
Damping ratio, critical damping and natural frequency

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Identify half-power frequencies \rightarrow Use bandwidth relation with natural frequency \rightarrow Compute damping ratio and convert to percent
key_insights: The phrase "power is half of the maximum" directly indicates half-power (−3 dB) frequencies.
For lightly damped SDOF systems, the bandwidth between half-power points is proportional to damping ratio.
Natural frequency must be in rad/s when using the bandwidth formula.

formulas_principles.name: Conversion from natural frequency in Hz to rad/s
formulas_principles.conditions: Used when natural frequency is given in cycles per second (Hz) but equations require rad/s.
formulas_principles.relevance: Needed to use the half-power bandwidth relation which is in terms of rad/s.

formulas_principles.name: Half-power bandwidth relation for damped SDOF
formulas_principles.conditions: Valid for lightly damped SDOF systems under harmonic excitation, relating damping ratio to half-power frequencies.
formulas_principles.relevance: Core formula to compute damping ratio from the given half-power frequencies.

formulas_principles.name: Damping ratio from bandwidth
formulas_principles.conditions: Derived directly from the half-power bandwidth relation.
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to calculate the numerical value of damping ratio.

formulas_principles.name: Damping ratio in percent
formulas_principles.conditions: Used when the answer is required as a percentage.
formulas_principles.relevance: Converts the dimensionless damping ratio to percent as requested in the question.

industry_examples: Estimating damping in aircraft wing or fuselage vibration tests from measured frequency response curves.
Determining damping in turbine blades or compressor blades from experimental modal testing using half-power bandwidth.
specific_systems: Vibration qualification of avionics racks mounted on aircraft structures.
Rotor-bearing systems in aero-engines where damping is estimated from resonance peaks.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Accurate estimation of damping from frequency response data is crucial for predicting vibration levels, fatigue life, and ensuring that structural resonances do not lead to failure in aerospace components.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using the given 10 Hz directly as \(\omega_n = 10\) instead of converting to rad/s.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They forget that Hz is cycles per second, not radians per second, and the bandwidth formula uses rad/s.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always check units: if a formula has \(\omega\), convert from Hz using \(\omega = 2\pi f\). Write the conversion explicitly in your solution.
common_mistakes.consequence: Damping ratio is underestimated by a factor of about \(2\pi\), giving a completely wrong percentage.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using \(\omega_2 + \omega_1\) instead of \(\omega_2 - \omega_1\) in the bandwidth formula.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Confusion between formulas for average frequency and bandwidth.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember: bandwidth is always a difference (high minus low). Write \(\Delta\omega = \omega_2 - \omega_1\) first, then plug into formulas.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to a very large, non-physical damping ratio.

common_mistakes.mistake: Thinking that "power is half of the maximum" means amplitude is half, and trying to use amplitude ratios directly.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They mix up power and amplitude; they may not recall that power is proportional to amplitude squared.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Recall that half-power corresponds to amplitude reduced by a factor of \(1/\sqrt{2}\), not 1/2. But for this question, you only need to recognize that these are half-power frequencies and use the bandwidth formula.
common_mistakes.consequence: May lead to using incorrect conditions or deriving the wrong relation for \(\zeta\).

common_mistakes.mistake: Using the damped natural frequency instead of the undamped natural frequency in the bandwidth formula.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They assume the resonance peak frequency equals the given 10 Hz, or they confuse \(\omega_d\) and \(\omega_n\).
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember that the standard half-power bandwidth relation is written with \(\omega_n\). For light damping, \(\omega_d \approx \omega_n\), but here \(\omega_n\) is explicitly given.
common_mistakes.consequence: Usually a small numerical error for light damping, but conceptually incorrect.

mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use when you see two half-power frequencies and need to find damping ratio.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: Hertz to Hat (\"^\" for angle): multiply by 2π
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Conversion from frequency in Hz to angular frequency in rad/s.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Whenever a formula uses \(\omega\) but data is in Hz.

flashcards.front: What is the half-power bandwidth formula relating \(\omega_1, \omega_2, \omega_n\) and damping ratio \(\zeta\) for a damped SDOF system?
flashcards.back: For lightly damped SDOF under harmonic excitation: \(\omega_2 - \omega_1 = 2\zeta\omega_n\). Thus, \(\zeta = (\omega_2 - \omega_1)/(2\omega_n)\).

flashcards.front: In vibration testing, what do the two frequencies at which power is half of its maximum represent?
flashcards.back: They are the half-power (−3 dB) frequencies, \(\omega_1\) and \(\omega_2\), on either side of the resonance peak. Their separation is the bandwidth used to estimate damping.

flashcards.front: How do you convert a natural frequency of 10 Hz to rad/s?
An SDOF system has \(\omega_n = 50\,\text{rad/s}\). Half-power frequencies are 48 and 52 rad/s. Estimate \(\zeta\).
Why is it wrong to use 10 Hz directly as \(\omega_n = 10\) in vibration formulas?
flashcards.back: Because \(\omega_n\) must be in rad/s. Hz is cycles/s; you must convert using \(\omega_n = 2\pi f_n\). Otherwise, damping and other results will be off by a factor of \(2\pi\).

real_world_context.application: Experimental modal analysis of aircraft structures
real_world_context.industry_example: Engineers excite a wing or fuselage panel with a shaker, measure the frequency response, and identify the half-power points around each resonance peak to estimate damping ratios.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Underestimating damping can lead to unsafe vibration levels and fatigue damage; overestimating it may lead to overly conservative and heavy designs.

real_world_context.application: Qualification of avionics and payloads for launch vehicles
real_world_context.industry_example: Electronics boxes are mounted on a shaker table, and their resonance peaks and bandwidths are measured to ensure they can withstand launch vibration spectra.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Incorrect damping estimation could result in under-designed mounts, causing failures during launch due to excessive vibration.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Identify that this is a standard half-power bandwidth problem. Convert 10 Hz to rad/s, compute bandwidth (difference of given frequencies), then apply \(\zeta = (\omega_2 - \omega_1)/(2\omega_n)\). It is a quick plug-in calculation.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck, remember typical structural damping is small (1–5%). Any answer much larger (e.g., >20%) is likely wrong.
exam_strategy.time_management: Allocate about 2 minutes: 30 s to interpret the half-power phrase, 30 s for unit conversion, and 1 min for arithmetic and checking.

search_keywords: mechanical vibrations Rao half power method
GATE AE vibrations damping ratio problems

alternative_methods.name: Derivation from frequency response function
alternative_methods.description: Start from the amplitude magnification factor of a damped SDOF system under harmonic excitation: \(H(r) = 1/\sqrt{(1 - r^2)^2 + (2\zeta r)^2}\), where \(r = \omega/\omega_n\). Set \(H(r) = H_{\max}/\sqrt{2}\) to represent half-power, solve for the two values of \(r\), and then relate them to \(\zeta\). This leads to the bandwidth relation for small \(\zeta\).
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Gives deeper understanding of where the bandwidth formula comes from; no need to memorize. Cons: Algebra is longer and not suitable under exam time pressure.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Use when deriving formulas in theory study sessions or if you forget the bandwidth relation and have time to re-derive.

connections_to_other_subjects.Control Systems: The concept of half-power bandwidth and −3 dB points is identical to bandwidth in Bode plots and filter design.
connections_to_other_subjects.Signals and Systems: Power spectral density and the relation between amplitude and power (power proportional to amplitude squared) underpin the half-power concept.
connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Flutter and aeroelastic instabilities depend strongly on structural damping; estimating damping from flight test data uses similar frequency response ideas.
connections_to_other_subjects.Structural Dynamics: Modal testing and finite element model updating rely on damping estimation from measured frequency response functions.

deeper_dive_topics: Derivation of half-power bandwidth formula from the exact frequency response function
Differences between viscous, structural, and Coulomb damping and their effect on frequency response
Experimental modal analysis techniques for aerospace structures
Nonlinear vibration and limitations of the half-power method for large-amplitude responses

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Single degree of freedom systems: free and forced vibration, damping, resonance
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Excellent question to test practical understanding of damping estimation from frequency response, directly relevant to structural dynamics in aerospace.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided general background on damped SDOF systems, natural and damped frequencies, and resonance, which supports the conceptual basis of this problem. However, the specific half-power bandwidth formula was not explicitly given, so the solution relied on standard vibration theory from internal knowledge.

future_questions_potential: Given a measured frequency response peak amplitude and half-power frequencies, ask students to compute both damping ratio and quality factor Q.
Provide time-domain free vibration decay data (logarithmic decrement) and frequency response half-power data, and ask to compare damping estimates from both methods.
Ask for the shift between undamped natural frequency and resonant frequency for a given damping ratio, and its effect on bandwidth.
Extend to multi-degree-of-freedom systems where closely spaced modes require careful bandwidth interpretation.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: A damped single degree of freedom system whose undamped natural frequency, omega_n = 10Hz, is subjected to sinusoidal external force. Power is half of the maximum for the two frequencies of 60.9469 rad/s and 64.7168 rad/s. The damping factor associated with the vibrating system (in %) is _______.
